'''Homeless dumping''' or '''patient dumping''' is the practice of [[hospital]]s or [[emergency service]]s releasing [[homeless]] patients on the streets instead of placing them with a [[homeless shelter]] or retaining them, especially when they may require expensive medical care with minimal government reimbursement from [[Medicaid]] or [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]].<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Dumped On Skid Row |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/05/17/60minutes/main2823079.shtml |work= |publisher=[[60 Minutes]] |date= May 17, 2007|accessdate=2007-05-21 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=L.A. charges hospital in dumping of homeless |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/15752013 |work= |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |date=November 16, 2006 |accessdate=2007-05-21 }}</ref> Many [[Homelessness and mental health|homeless people who have mental health problems]] can no longer find a place in a [[psychiatric hospital]] since the trend towards mental health [[deinstitutionalization]] from the 1960s onwards.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Scherl DJ, Macht LB |title=Deinstitutionalization in the absence of consensus |journal=Hosp Community Psychiatry |volume=30 |issue=9 |pages=599–604 |date=September 1979 |pmid=223959 |url=http://ps.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=223959 |doi=10.1176/ps.30.9.599 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Rochefort DA |title=Origins of the "Third psychiatric revolution": the Community Mental Health Centers Act of 1963 |journal=J Health Polit Policy Law |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=1–30 |date=Spring 1984 |pmid=6736594 |url=http://jhppl.dukejournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=6736594 |doi=10.1215/03616878-9-1-1}}</ref>
== History == The term "patient dumping" was first mentioned in the New York Times in articles published in the late 1870s describing the practice of private New York hospitals transporting poor and sickly patients by horse drawn ambulance to [[NYC Health + Hospitals/Bellevue|Bellevue Hospital]], the city's preeminent public facility.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Abel|first=Emily|date=May 2011|title=Patient Dumping in New York City, 1877–1917|url=|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=101|issue=5|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2010.300005|pmid=|access-date=|via=|pages=789–795}}</ref> The jarring ride and lack of stabilized care typically resulted in death of the patient and outrage of the public. Notwithstanding the passage of city ordinances prohibiting the practice it continued.<ref name=":0" />
"Patient dumping" resurfaced in the 1980s, nationwide, with private hospitals refusing to examine or treat the poor and uninsured in the emergency departments (ED) and transferring them to public hospitals for further care and treatment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schiff|first=Robert L.|last2=Ansell|first2=David A.|last3=Schlosser|first3=James E.|last4=Idris|first4=Ahamed H.|last5=Morrison|first5=Ann|last6=Whitman|first6=Steven|date=1986-02-27|title=Transfers to a Public Hospital|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1056/NEJM198602273140905|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=314|issue=9|pages=552–557|doi=10.1056/NEJM198602273140905|issn=0028-4793|pmid=3945293}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=History and Health Policy in the United States: Putting the Past Back in|last=|first=|publisher=|year=2006|isbn=9780813538389|location=|pages=280|via=}}</ref> This refusal of care resulted in patient deaths and public outcry culminating with the passage of a federal anti-patient dumping law in 1986 known as the [[Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act]].
==Usage== *[[Associated Press]]; February 9, 2007; [[Los Angeles]]. A hospital van dropped off a homeless paraplegic man on [[Skid Row, Los Angeles|Skid Row]] and left him crawling in the street with nothing more than a soiled gown and a broken colostomy bag, police said.... Police said the incident was a case of ''"homeless dumping"'' and were questioning officials from the hospital.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17062674/ Police probe alleged L.A. homeless dumping: Hospital van reportedly spotted dropping off paraplegic man on Skid Row], [[MSNBC]] via [[Associated Press]], February 9, 2007</ref> *[[Associated Press]], October 25, 2006; [[Los Angeles]]. "L.A. Police Allege ''Homeless Dumping''." Authorities have launched a criminal investigation into suspected dumping of homeless people on Skid Row after police witnessed ambulances leaving five people on a street there during the weekend.
